Review Single-atom iron catalysts for peroxymonosulfate-based advanced oxidation processes: Coordination structure versus reactive species Cheng Cheng a b Wei Ren b Hui Zhang a * Xiaoguang Duan b * Shaobin Wang b * a Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, School of Resource and Environmental Sciences, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430079, Hubei, China Department of Environmental Science and Engineering School of Resource and Environmental Sciences Wuhan University Wuhan Hubei 430079 China Department of Environmental Science and Engineering, School of Resource and Environmental Sciences, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430079, Hubei, China b School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia School of Chemical Engineering The University of Adelaide Adelaide SA 5005 Australia School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia * Corresponding author. ABSTRACT Heterogeneous peroxymonosulfate (PMS)-based oxidation technology for water treatment requires innovative catalysts for efficient and selective production of desired reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as free radicals, singlet oxygen, catalyst-PMS* complexes, and high-valent metal-oxo species. Single-atom catalysts are featured with the maximized atom utilization as well as uniform and well-defined active sites, holding a great promise for effective and selective PMS activation. However, the structure-activity/selectivity relationships have not yet been well revealed owing to multiple ROS generation pathways and their complex interplay. Herein, we focus on the mechanisms of PMS activation by single-atom iron catalysts and identify the relationships of the geometric and electronic structures of single atom Fe centers to selective production of different reactive species/pathways. Moreover, in situ/operando techniques to monitor the dynamic evolution of active sites under practical working conditions and design of binuclear metal sites for synergistic catalysis will also be discussed. Graphical Abstract This review provides a critical analysis of the mechanism of peroxymonosulfate activation by single-atom iron catalysts. It aims to identify the structure-activity/selectivity relationships in the controllable generation of radical and nonradical species for environmental remediation and beyond. Keywords Peroxymonosulfate activation Single-atom iron catalyst Radical Nonradical Water treatment Environmental remediation 1 Introduction The rapid increase in global industrialization in the past centuries has resulted in the disposal of excessive toxic pollutants into the environment, seriously threatening the aquatic ecosystem and human health [1,2]. Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) are appealing techniques to treat these toxic pollutants. Leveraging diverse reactive oxygen species (ROS), AOPs are sought to oxidize or even mineralize recalcitrant and toxic organic pollutants to CO2, H2O, and other ions. Persulfates were introduced as an alternative to H2O2 and O3 to generate sulfate radicals (SO4 •–), which show superiorities of a higher oxidizing capacity, better selectivity, wider pH applicability and a longer lifetime than hydroxyl radicals (•OH) [3-5]. Peroxymonosulfate (PMS), a typical persulfate marketed as 2KHSO5·KHSO4·K2SO4, is a derivative of H2O2 in which one H-atom is replaced by a SO3 – group. However, the solid nature of PMS makes it more economical for storage and transportation than H2O2. PMS possesses a shorter O–O bond length (1.46 Å) and thus higher bond dissociation energy (377 kJ mol–1) than those of H2O2 (1.49 Å and 195 kJ mol–1) [6], suggesting that PMS requires more energy for the homolytic cleavage of the O–O bond to generate radicals (i.e., energy activation by light or heat) [7,8]. However, the asymmetric structure of PMS makes it more vulnerable to being activated by transition metals (e.g., Co(II), Fe2O3, CuFe2O4). Heterogeneous catalysts have attracted great interest owing to the ease of their recycling in practical applications. Typically, the journey of the heterogeneous catalysts begins from the single-metal oxides (e.g., Co3O4, MnO2, Fe3O4, CuO) [9] to mixed metal oxides (e.g., spinels and perovskites [10,11]), and then carbonaceous materials [12]. With the development of heterogeneous catalysts, researchers have discovered emerging reaction pathways/ROS such as singlet oxygen (1O2), catalyst-PMS*, and high-valent metal-oxo species in PMS-based AOPs [13-15]. These nonradical species possess a moderate oxidizing capacity that can achieve selective and fast oxidation of target pollutants even in complex water matrices, superior to the radical species. However, a further development of heterogeneous PMS activation technology to achieve oriented generation of radical and nonradical species is greatly restricted by the structural complexity of artificial nanomaterials. For example, graphitic carbons and oxygen functional groups (ketonic groups) in nanocarbons are proposed to be the respective active sites for generating a catalyst-PMS* complex and 1O2, while various crystal structures, facets, and defects exhibit different PMS activation behaviors in metal oxides [12,16-18]. Tackling this challenge requires an in-depth understanding of the structure of active sites and fine-tuning to establish the structure-activity/selectivity correlations. In this regard, emerging single-atom catalysts (SACs) featuring the uniform dispersion of active sites on supports and well-defined coordination (similar to molecular catalysts) can be a promising platform for heterogeneous catalysis [19,20]. Although SACs were first designed to downsize the noble metals to maximize their dispersion and utilization efficiency [21,22], the single metal site shows distinct reactivity and selectivity compared with their nanoparticle (NP) counterparts in many catalytic reactions owing to its unique geometric and electronic structures [23,24]. Furthermore, the abundant d orbital electrons of transition metals can remarkably regulate the local electronic structure through strong electronic metal-support interactions, giving rise to controllable regulation of active site properties in a catalytic reaction [25]. Therefore, SACs can be an ideal model to solve the above-mentioned challenge of establishing structure-activity/selectivity correlations in PMS activation. Various metal atoms (e.g., Fe, Co, Cu, Mn) have been successfully anchored on carbon supports with atomic dispersion and exhibited remarkable PMS activation reactivity [26-30]. Iron-based catalysts have been of particular interest in environmental catalysis due to their affordability, versatility, redox-active properties, and low toxicity. Various single atom iron catalysts (SAICs) have been fabricated for AOPs, such as peroxides activation [31-38] and electro-Fenton [39-42] reactions, exhibiting outstanding reactivity for organic pollutant degradation. As for PMS activation, diverse reactive species involving free radicals, 1O2, catalyst-PMS*, and high-valent iron-oxo species (HVI) are reported with different redox capacities and selectivity. However, there lacks a review discussing the distinct reaction behaviors of SAICs and the modulation of active sites in PMS activation that affect the activity in persulfate activation and selectivity toward reactive species generation, despite the recent reviews on the history, synthesis and application of SACs in AOPs [43-49]. Therefore, we present a review of the SAICs for PMS activation and discuss the involved reactive species and their detailed generation pathways, as well as the engineering of active sites for enhanced and selective generation of ROS/pathways at the molecular level, aiming to establish the structure-activity/selectivity correlations in this exciting field. The main structure of the review is presented in Fig. 1 . We first summarize the synthesis strategies, characterization techniques, and structure evolution of single atom metal sites. The developed SAICs for PMS activation are then comprehensively examined. We focus on the generation pathways of the different reactive species, such as free radicals, 1O2, catalyst-PMS*, and HVI, as well as the modulation of the single atom Fe sites and relations with their geometric and electronic structures for ROS selective production. We conclude our review by discussing the further development of SACs for AOPs, from mechanistic exploration to rational catalyst design toward practical environmental remediation. 2 Synthesis, characterization, and formation of SACs 2.1 Synthesis strategies The synthesis strategies to prepare well-defined SACs are constantly broadening in the past decade. We here briefly summarize the most widely applied methods. Further information can be obtained from the comprehensive reviews [25,50-53]. The basic principle is to overcome the aggregation tendency of isolated single atoms into NPs during the synthesis process. This can be achieved by constructing the strong covalent bonds between metal single atom and the coordination atoms from supports to win against the metal-metal bonds of metal NPs. Many advanced strategies have been developed, which can be categorized as “bottom-up” and “top-down” routes based on the forms of the starting precursors. 2.1.1 “Bottom-up” strategies In a “bottom-up” synthetic process, mononuclear metal complexes are the starting precursors, and the key is dispersing the mononuclear metal complexes and stabilizing the formed metal single atoms during the post-removal of extra ligands. Therefore, various strategies such as coordination site construction, spatial confinement, and defect engineering have been developed to accomplish this goal while increasing the metal loading. For the strategy of coordination site construction, the anchoring sites involving polymers and their derivatives [54-59], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and their derivatives [60-69], and heteroatom dopants on modified carbon materials [70-76] are constructed to stabilize the SACs. Polymers and their derivatives possess abundant heteroatoms such as O, N, P, and S, which can strongly interact with and anchor metal single atoms. For example, He et al. [54] developed a universal precursor-dilution strategy, preparing 25 noble and non-noble metallic SACs, in which metal-chelated tetraphenylporphyrin (TPP) was co-polymerized with free TPP as the diluent, followed by pyrolysis. The metal cations could be strongly chelated by N atoms in TPP, and the mean distance between metal atoms dispersed on the as-prepared polymer matrix was enlarged by the dilution, favoring the formation of SACs. MOFs possess abundant metal nodes and versatile ligands to coordinate and stabilize target metal atoms in the skeleton of MOFs. In addition, the organic ligands in MOFs can be easily transformed to a N-doped porous carbon support via pyrolysis. Therefore, MOFs and their derivatives can serve as excellent precursors for the synthesis of SACs. For example, Chen et al. [61] designed a single atom W catalyst, in which WCl5 was encapsulated in the skeleton of UiO-66-NH2, followed by pyrolysis and hydrofluoric acid leaching processes. The abundant uncoordinated amine groups in the UiO-66-NH2 can facilitate the bonding and stabilization of W atoms to prevent aggregation. Another most frequently used MOF precursor for the preparation of SACs is ZIF-8 utilizing the low boiling point of Zn atom (907 °C). Yin et al. [65] reported a bimetallic Zn/Co ZIFs pyrolysis strategy to prepare single atom Co catalysts. Furthermore, by regulating the molar ratio of Zn/Co in the ZIF precursors and annealing temperature in the post-treatment process, the metal particle size [77] and coordination number of single Co sites [64] can be precisely regulated. Other SACs based on Fe and Mn can also be constructed by this strategy using the corresponding metal precursors through an ionic exchange with Zn2+ ions [67,69]. In this strategy, the single-atom site and N-doped carbon support can be concurrently formed during the facile pyrolysis of ZIF precursors, which suggests that the existing support may not be necessary for preparing carbon-supported SACs. Nevertheless, taking advantage of an existing carbon support and introducing heteroatom dopants (e.g., N, O, S) into carbon frameworks can provide more anchoring sites for metal species, further increasing the metal loading. For instance, Zhao et al. [71] reported a general cascade anchoring strategy for the production of SACs, where the abundant oxygen functional groups on the carbon support could effectively anchor the glucose-chelated metal ions that can be transformed to M–N x moieties by a melamine-assisted pyrolysis process (Fig. 2(a) ). Such an anchoring-protecting strategy allows for producing SACs with high metal loading up to 12.1 wt%. Similarly, oxygen functional groups on the carbon surface would help anchor the metal phthalocyanine onto carbon nanotubes by strengthening π–π interactions from atomically dispersed single atom metal sites with a well-defined molecular structure [74,75]. For the spatial confinement strategy, porous materials (e.g., MOFs, covalent-organic frameworks, and zeolite) with uniform pores and regular structures can serve as hosts to encapsulate and spatially disperse suitable metal complexes to prevent aggregation. Among them, ZIF-8 is one of the most used porous materials for the preparation of SACs owing to its unique pore size and cavity diameter. Li and co-workers [78-80] developed a general host-guest strategy to fabricate a series of SACs. Taking the preparation of SAIC as an example, iron (III) acetylacetonate (Fe(acac)3) was used as an Fe precursor, which possesses a molecular diameter (ca. 9.7 Å) between the pore size (3.4 Å) and cavity diameter (11 Å) of ZIF-8. Therefore, one Fe(acac)3 molecule can be in situ trapped in one cage of ZIF-8 during the formation process. A post-pyrolysis process can in situ reduce caged Fe(acac)3 to N-coordinated single atoms with a high Fe loading up to 2.16 wt% (Fig. 2(b)). More strikingly, changing the type of metal precursor can regulate the chemical environment and coordination structure of the metal single atoms. For example, when iron (II) phthalocyanine (FePc) with a molecular size of 14.6 Å was used to replace Fe(acac)3, the ZIF-8 cage would burst to break the spatial confinement of microcavity but form the enlarged mesopore structure and edge-hosted single atom Fe sites after the post-pyrolysis and acid leaching processes [81]. Besides, when a P-containing precursor (e.g., triphenylphosphine [82] and phytic acid [83]) was encapsulated in the ZIF-8 cage, the M–N4 coordination structure can be transformed into the M–N3–P1 coordination, which can enhance the electron density of metal sites and regulate the adsorption of crucial intermediates in catalytic reactions. For the defect design strategy, the defects on supports can provide unsaturated coordination sites to capture mononuclear metal complexes [84,85]. For example, a facile wetness impregnation-pyrolysis method was developed by Yao and co-workers [84] to prepare single-atom Ni catalysts utilizing Di-vacancy on graphene to trap atomic Ni species (Fig. 2(c)). 2.1.2 “Top-down” strategies A “bottom-up” synthetic route usually features the facile preparation procedure (e.g., by a simple one-step pyrolysis process) that obtains SACs with a considerable metal loading. However, in the “bottom-up” methods, the formed single-atom sites are not all accessible to the support external surface that may restrain the mass transportation and catalytic activity in the bulk. On the contrary, a “top-down” synthetic route can use bulk metal or metal NPs as precursors for preparing SACs, favoring the formation of catalytically active single-atom sites on the (near-)surface of the catalysts. The principle of “top-down” synthetic process comprises the cleavage of the M–M bond and subsequent formation of new bond between formed metal single-atom sites and coordination sites of supports, where the interaction of the latter is stronger than the former [88,89]. High synthesis temperature provides energy to break the metal-metal bond, and the annealing atmosphere helps generate volatile metal species to develop individual sites. The supports usually necessitate holding rich coordination sites to capture the migrating metal atoms and form strong interactions with the coordination sites to inhibit metal sintering. For example, Li and co-workers [90] reported that high-temperature pyrolysis of metal NPs encapsulated ZIF-8 in an inert atmosphere could in situ convert the noble metal NPs (Pd, Pt, Au) into thermally stable single atoms on N-doped carbon. The competition between Pd–N and Pd–Pd bonds essentially determined whether the transformation from NPs to single atoms can be realized. Similarly, N-doped carbon-supported Ni NPs could also be converted to surface-bound single atoms through thermal atomization, in which the strong coordination with N splits Ni atoms from Ni NPs and generates Ni–N x structure. Meanwhile, Ni NPs would break the surface C–C bonds and drill into the carbon matrix to form porous structure (Fig. 2(d)) [86]. Li and co-workers [91] also developed a gas-migration method enabling direct transformation of bulk metal into carbon-supported single atoms, in which the flowing NH3 atmosphere could coordinate with metal atoms (Cu, Co, Ni) from the bulk metal surface to form volatile M(NH3) x at high temperatures and migrate to the defect-rich N-doped porous carbon support to develop SACs. 2.2 Characterizations and structure evolution The characterization of SACs requires a whole toolbox of techniques, involving microscopy and spectroscopy, such as scanning tunneling microscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), infrared spectroscopy, and Mössbauer spectroscopy, as well as theoretical studies. There have been many reviews on the characterization of SACs [92-96]. We here concisely summarize the most widely applied tools for the visualization and determination of the structural and electronic properties of single atoms and highlight the recent advances in using in situ/operando techniques to recognize the structure evolution of single atoms during the synthesis process for mechanistic insights. 2.2.1 Characterization techniques TEM is one of the most powerful techniques to directly observe mono dispersion of the supported metal atoms. In TEM, a high-energy electron beam is transmitted through the sample and carries and the information from the interaction with the sample to realize the visualization. The electron beam can be convergent to form a small probe and scan across a region of the sample, which is referred to as scanning TEM (STEM). The transmitted electrons are scattered by the atoms in the sample, and those scattered to a high angle can be collected by a high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) detector to form a HAADF image [96]. The scattering probability is approximately proportional to the atomic number. Therefore, the “heavy atoms” (metals), visualized as the brighter spots, can be well distinguished from the “light carriers”. Employing an additional aberration corrector (AC) can further achieve a sub-Ångstrom resolution, making AC-HAADF-STEM indispensable for the characterization of SACs. X-ray characterization is a powerful method that provides information on crystal structure, electronic structure, and coordination environment [94]. XAS is one of the most sensitive and capable techniques to characterize SACs. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES), resulting from the excitation of core electrons to the valence and conduction bands, can provide local electronic structure information of the probed element by comparison with reference samples. The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) can illustrate the local geometric structure and coordination environment of single atoms, i.e., the bond length and coordination number by fitting analysis, which provides a strong evidence to distinguish single atom sites from NPs. However, the limitation of XAS is that, as a non-spatially resolved bulk technique, XAS provides average information on the coordination environment of metal species, which may not be able to discriminate unique structures from nonuniform and mixed structures [97,98]. Besides, XPS has also been widely used for characterizing the compositions and electronic structures (e.g., the valence state of metal sites) of the substrate, as a complementary tool to distinguish the coordinated metal cations from the zero-valent metal NPs. Mössbauer spectroscopy is another high-resolution technique to determine the coordination geometry, chemical state, and spin state of Mössbauer-active elements (e.g., Fe, Sn, Ru, Ir, etc.) in SACs [99,100]. It can quantitatively determine the catalyst phase, structure, and oxidation state in the bulk and at the surface of the catalyst, which is sometimes difficult to acquire by other techniques. For example, using room-temperature 57Fe Mo?ssbauer spectroscopy, Wu et al. [101] and Jaouen et al. [102] both quantitatively identified two types of Fe–N4 sites with different local structures of high-spin Fe–N4–C12 and low- or intermediate-spin Fe–N4–C10 sites, which were hard to be distinguished by XAS techniques. 2.2.2 Structure evolution of single-atom metal sites Besides ex situ characterization, an in situ/operando technique enables the study of the dynamics and synthesis mechanism of SACs. The in situ environmental TEM (ETEM), XAS, and XRD have been utilized and provided mechanistic insights into the structure evolution of single atom sites during the synthesis process [90,103-106]. Han et al. [104] utilized in situ ETEM and XRD to observe the ion-NP-single atom evolution of transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) during a typical impregnation-pyrolysis process. They demonstrated a two-step formation process of N-doped carbon-supported SACs, metal sintering from ions to NPs (500–600 °C), and the NP conversion into single atoms at higher temperatures (700–800 °C). Similarly, Wu and co-workers employed in situ XAS to elucidate the formation mechanism of Co–N4 sites via a typical “bottom-up” approach, using ZIF-8 derived N-doped porous carbon as the host for Co ion adsorption and subsequent thermal activation [106]. They reported that the adsorbed Co(NO3)2 precursor first transformed to Co hydroxide at room temperature, and then underwent dehydration/decomposition to form an oxide-rich mixture at up to 523 °C, to Co–N4 with a minor Co metal component at ca. 700 °C, and entirely to atomically dispersed Co–N4 sites at 900 °C. They also found that the formation processes of Fe–N4 and Ni–N4 sites follow a similar transition procedure from ion-(hydro-)oxides to clusters and eventually to single atoms during the pyrolysis [87,107]. The difference for various metal centers lies in the different thermal energy requirements for the initial formation of M–N4 sites and the subsequent structure optimization for a desired catalytic behavior. The transformation from FeO x clusters to atomically dispersed Fe–N x sites is already completed at 400 °C, but requires 700 °C to optimize the Fe–N4 coordination and local structures to achieve the optimal electrochemical activity (Fig. 2(e)). The formation of Ni–N4 sites requires a temperature of 900 °C and even higher, e.g., 1200 °C for optimized CO2 electroreduction activity and selectivity, where Ni–N3 active sites with optimal local structures are formed. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations also showed that removing a Fe atom from a FeOx particle to coordinate with the surrounding N4 vacancy is thermodynamically favorable. In addition, Zhang et al. [103] investigated not only the chemical evolution but also the microstructural formation of Co/Zn-ZIF during pyrolysis using in situ (S)TEM and electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS). They demonstrated a four-step evolution process at 200–1000 °C, which is comprised of (1) reduction and aggregation of Co species to metallic clusters at 500 °C; (2) dispersion of Co species to single atoms on carbonized support at 700–800 °C; (3) re-aggregation of atomically dispersed Co species to molten NPs that would move and etch the supports to produce porous structure at 850 °C; and (4) sublimation of the rest cobalt carbide NPs at 1000 °C. Han et al. [105] also employed in situ XAS to study the evolution dynamics for the synthesis of single atoms during a general dissolution-and-carbonization process. They found the metal species- and temperature-dependent formation processes of M–N4 and M–O4 sites and demonstrated that the central metal atoms coordinated with O at low temperature could be replaced by N (or C) at high temperatures. These discoveries on the structure evolution of single atoms provide valuable guidance for the controlled synthesis of SACs with on-demand structures. For example, Wu and co-workers [101] employed ultrafine Fe2O3 NPs as a metal source and encapsulated them into ZIF-8 to fabricate SAICs by pyrolysis. The Fe contents could be gradually released from the Fe2O3 NPs and captured by the defective N ligands from ZIF-8 during the high-temperature pyrolysis. This process can remarkably populate the site density of atomically dispersed Fe–N4, superior to the typically used mononuclear metal precursors such as FeCl3 and Fe(NO3)3. 3 SAICs for PMS activation 3.1 Overview of the structure of SAICs for PMS activation The various SAICs reported for PMS activation have been summarized in Table 1 . It can be observed that environmental researchers prefer the “bottom-up” strategy for catalyst synthesis because of a facile operation. Employing biochar as a carbon support [122,125,129] or directly using Fe-containing biomass, such as Enteromorpha [133] as a Fe and carbon source will further decrease the synthesis cost. Fe contents in SAICs typically vary from 0.41 wt% to 9.0 wt%, depending on the synthesis methods (Fig. 3(a) ). Nitrogen is the most frequently used coordination element for anchoring Fe single atoms on the carbon support and most likely forming a four pyridinic N coordinated Fe–N4 structure with the Fe–N bond length of ca. 2.00 Å (Figs. 3(b) and (c)). Therefore, we refer the single atom Fe center to the Fe–N4 (pyridinic N) structure if not specified. A previous review has suggested that many SACs achieve 3 to 4 times faster pollutant degradation kinetics compared to metal and oxide NP counterparts [44]. Considering the much lower metal contents in SACs than NPs, SACs exhibit significantly higher turnover frequencies (TOFs) when the reaction kinetics are normalized to the active site density. Meanwhile, the average metal leaching from SACs is over 1 order of magnitude lower than NP counterparts for PMS activation owing to the strong metal-support (Fe-N x ) interactions. This metal-support interaction induces a unique electronic structure of single atom Fe centers, where the electrons can be transferred from Fe and C atoms toward the adjacent N atoms, accumulating in pyridinic N (i.e., Fe δ+–N δ––C δ+) in the Fe–N4 structure (Fig. 3(e)) [144]. Therefore, the Fe center region has the most positive electrostatic potential value. Considering the negative electrostatic potentials of O atoms in PMS, the Fe center is the most attractive site for PMS adsorption (Fig. 3(f)). This electron delocalization around the Fe center and the utmost dispersion of these sites thus afford SAICs excellent catalytic activity in PMS activation. SAICs with uniform active sites are expected to help establish the structure-activity/selectivity relationships. However, extensive studies reported that diverse reactive species involving radicals, 1O2, catalyst-PMS* complexes, and HVI were generated even in the similar type of Fe–N4 site. Meanwhile, numerous efforts have been directed towards fine-tuning the intrinsic electronic structure of atomic Fe sites for PMS activation by modulating the coordination atom to generate Fe–N3, Fe–N3–P1, Fe–N2–O2, and Fe–N4 (pyrrolic N) sites, introducing the guest group to generate an Fe–N5 site, and incorporating environmental atom to generate an Fe2–N8 site (Fig. 4 ). On one hand, these modulations increase the catalytic activity of the materials for ROS generation. On the other hand, they intensify the complexity to correlate the structure properties with activity and selectivity due to inadequate characterization and understanding of the active site structure (Fig. 5(a) ). For example, substituting two N coordination atoms with two O atoms to create a Fe–N2–O2 site can alter the spin state of the Fe site, augmenting its electron-donating capacity [136]. However, the resulting generation of three different nonradical species (1O2 [125], HVI [136], and catalyst-PMS* [133]) renders it challenging to establish the relationship between the active site structure and ROS generation selectivity (Fig. 5(b)). These observations suggest the necessity of in-depth evaluation of the properties of active sites and the associated ROS generation mechanism for establishing the structure-activity/selectivity correlations in PMS activation and designing highly efficient SACs for various reactions. 3.2 Fundamentals of PMS activation on SAICs Taking the Fe–N4 (pyridinic N) structure as an example, the activation of PMS usually proceeds via three steps. The first step is the adsorption of HSO5 – ions onto the single atom Fe center with varying molecular alignments. According to the molecular structure of PMS, the O atoms of PMS can be divided into three categories: one O atom in hydroxy that bonds to H atom; one peroxy O atom that bonds to both S and O atoms; and three terminal O atoms that only bond to S atom (Fig. 6(a) ) [145]. The preferentially adsorbed O atom and the adsorption structure depend on the microenvironment around the Fe center including the geometric and electronic structures. The second step is the charge transfer between the active Fe center and adsorbed HSO5 –, resulting in the change of charge density and even cleavage of O–O bond of HSO5 –. This step proceeds by forming different transition adsorption states, which can be affected by the initial adsorption structure in the first step. The third step is the detachment of the activated HSO5 – through a spontaneous release of the reactive species (such as free radicals and 1O2) or decomposition of the surface-bound species with other substrates (such as catalyst-PMS* and HVI) to regenerate the active site (Fig. 6(b)). In general, the first step is usually thermodynamically favorable owing to the strong electron polarization of single atom Fe centers. The second step determines the type of the generated reactive species, i.e., the reaction thermodynamics. The third step can control the reactive species generation rate, i.e., the kinetics of the overall reaction. Therefore, the diverse PMS adsorption structures on the single atom Fe sites with intricate microenvironment result in complex reaction pathways. Besides, uncertainties still exist in the identification of the reactive species and their evolution pathways on the catalyst. Methods involving electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), chemical probing, and chemical quenching experiments have been well-established. However, the complex interaction between probe/quencher and hybrid reactive species (especially for the nonradical species) makes the results confusing and probably leads to a misleading conclusion [146]. Therefore, we here discuss the generation mechanism of these species and summarize the critical factors influencing their generation from both theoretical and experimental aspects. The thermodynamics and kinetics of reactive species generation are expected to be correlated with the structure of single atom Fe sites, such as geometric structure, electronic state, and spin state. The methods to regulate the properties of the active Fe sites for achieving on-demand activity and ROS selectivity are also summarized, which will guide the design of other advanced SACs for PMS-based environmental remediation and beyond. Specific attention during the reactive species identification is also highlighted. 3.3 Generation, regulation, and identification of radicals Different from the metal or metal oxide NP counterparts, only a few works reported the generation of free radicals (SO4 •– and •OH) over Fe–N4 to dominate the pollutant oxidation [111]. The generation pathway of radicals on SAICs is similar to dissolved metal ions, where one electron is transferred from the single atom Fe center to the coordinated O atom of PMS to break the O–O bond and generate either SO4 •– or •OH (Fig. 6(b)) [111]. Besides, the generated SO4 •– can undergo a hydrolysis reaction with H2O/OH– to produce •OH [147]. Theoretical studies suggested that the peroxy O adsorption structure favors the generation of •OH, and that the hydroxy O adsorption structure favors the generation of SO4 •–, requiring 0.71 and 1.71 eV, respectively, which are higher than other nonradical pathways (0.64 and 0.48 eV for 1O2 and HVI, respectively) (Fig. 6(c)). This possibly explains the limited reports on free radical generation from the Fe–N4 site [144]. The main reason is that the electron density of the single atom Fe sites is too low to transfer sufficient electrons to PMS for O–O bond cleavage, compared with metal and metal oxide NP counterparts. Therefore, regulating the microenvironment of Fe centers to increase the electron density is a rational way to strengthen the generation of radical species. P-coordination to form Fe–N3–P1 structure [110,113] and electronic synergy with Fe clusters or NPs [108,109,112] are reported to be effective. For example, P-doping can augment the electron density of Fe and alter the spin-state of Fe 3d electrons to a medium spin state, thus increasing the orbital overlapping between Fe 3d and O 2p orbitals of PMS and facilitating electron transfer to PMS for radical generation (Fig. 7 ) [113]. Meanwhile, the sustainable generation of radicals necessitates fast FeIII/FeII redox cycling for electron donation. Qian et al. [111] reported that constructing the pyrrolic N coordination around the Fe atom extends the delocalized π orbital and elevates the energy of Fe 3d orbitals, thus accelerating the FeIII/FeII cycle for radical generation (Fig. 7). Besides the strong oxidizing radicals (SO4 •– and •OH), some studies reported the generation of superoxide radicals (O2 •–) as major reactive species for pollutant oxidation, despite its less oxidizing capacity (E 0 (O2/O2 •–) = –0.33 VSHE) [114-118,148]. They proposed that O2 •– was generated by the catalyzed self-decomposition of PMS on single atom Fe sites [114,117,118] or the reaction of the in situ generated H2O2 and •OH on the Fe–N4 site [115,116]. The modulation of atomic Fe sites for enhancing the generation of O2 •– has not been reported and warrants a further exploration. The probes for radical identification include EPR trapping agents (e.g., 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) and 5-tert-butoxycarbonyl-5-methyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (BMPO)) and chemical probes such as terephthalic acid, coumarin, benzoic acid, nitrobenzene, and nitro blue tetrazolium (for O2 •–) [6]. They can trap the radicals to generate specific products or specifically react with the radicals with high second-order rate constants. The in situ spectroscopy techniques, specifically Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra and Raman spectra are powerful tools to identify the key intermediates during the PMS activation process for radical generation [108,111,113]. Typically, a PMS solution manifests three Raman peaks at ca. 881, 979, and 1059 cm–1, corresponding to the stretching vibration of the O–O bond, symmetric stretching vibration of SO4 2–, and symmetric stretching vibration of –SO3 group in HSO5 –, respectively (Fig. 8(a) ) [113]. When PMS interacts with the atomic Fe site, observable shifts occur in the peaks associated with the O–O bond and –SO3 group [113]. Furthermore, a new peak, situated around 780–840 cm–1, may emerge, correlating with the surface-bound SO4* as a key reaction intermediate during the generation of SO4 •– (Figs. 8(b) and (c)) [108,111]. The contribution of radicals to pollutant oxidation is usually studied by quenching experiments. For SO4 •– and •OH, methanol and tert-butanol are most widely used [7]. However, a high concentration of alcohols may change solution polarity, which affects the surface properties of catalysts and inhibits the adsorption of reactants [149]. Besides, the reaction between radicals and alcohols induces the generation of organic radicals, which may undesirably produce H2O2 [150]. These phenomena can lead to inaccurate results. In these circumstances, the probe reagents (such as benzoic acid or nitrobenzene) can be used as an alternative quencher. For O2 •–, p-benzoquinone (p-BQ) is widely used. However, the direct decomposition of PMS by p-BQ probably results in an overestimated contribution of O2 •– [151]. Considering the low oxidizing capacity of O2 •–, its major oxidation contribution needs a careful re-evaluation. Additionally, of particular note, the so-called surface-bound radicals were reported when the reaction rate was not obviously affected by the quenchers but the probe methods verify the generation of considerable amounts of radicals [152]. However, the identification techniques for surface-bound radicals are still limited. Recently, Xie et al. [153] employed in-situ cyclic voltammetry-electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance (CV-EQCM) technology to quantitatively identify the surface-bound SO4 •– in a single-atom cobalt catalyst/PMS system. Further studies for identification of the surface-bound radicals are required to precisely distinguish them from free radicals and surface-confined nonradical species (e.g., complexes). 3.4 Generation, regulation, and identification of 1O2 1O2 (represented as 1∠gO2) is an excited state of O2 in which the spin of one of the unpaired electrons is changed to yield two electrons with opposite spins [13]. 1O2 is a highly selective oxidant that reacts almost exclusively with unsaturated organics via electrophilic addition and electron abstraction. Even so, the kinetics of 1O2 reactions with most organic compounds are also much slower than those with radicals (second-order rate constants from 105 to 106 L mol–1 s–1 for 1O2 and around 109 L mol–1 s–1 for radicals). The substrate-specific reactivity of 1O2 and low standard reduction potential of 1O2 (0.81 VNHE) may contradict the purpose of AOPs, that is, abating a wide range of organic compounds that are recalcitrant to the parent oxidants. However, the feature of high selectivity in nonradical oxidation can be useful in treating complex matrices to avoid background interference and minimize chemical input. Many studies reported the dominant role of 1O2 in pollutant oxidation in the different SAICs/PMS systems and some even claimed nearly 100% selectivity for 1O2 production [27,119-128]. The terminal O adsorption on single atom Fe sites is the most favorable structure for the generation of 1O2 (Fig. 6(b)) [27,120,121,123-125,128,144]. There is, however, no consensus on the detailed generation pathways of 1O2. The proposed 1O2 generation mechanisms involve the electron-deficient single-atom Fe center catalyzed (1) recombination of two HSO5 –/SO5 2– molecules [119] or (2) two SO5 •– intermediates (Fig. 9(a) ) [120,121,123,124,127], (3) combination of two O* intermediates [27,125] (Fig. 9(b)), iv) disproportionation of in situ generated O2 •– intermediates from either dissolved oxygen [126,127] or PMS (Figs. 9(c) and (d)) [128], and (5) direct oxidation of HSO5 – [122]. The pathways of (1), (2), (4), and (5) have also been reported on metal/metal oxide NPs and carbon materials [12,154]. Gao et al. [27] investigated the 1O2 generation pathway on the Fe–N4 site (pathway (3))) using first-principles calculations. They demonstrated that the most reasonable reaction pathway for 1O2 production is PMS → OH* → O* → 1O2, where OH* and O* represent the reaction intermediates adsorbed on the active site (Fig. 9(b)). A PMS molecule could be first spontaneously divided into OH* and SO4* moieties on one Fe–N4 site. Then OH* moiety transformed and adsorbed onto another Fe–N4 site for the subsequent 1O2 generation reaction, and SO4* was released in the form of H2SO4. The adsorbed OH* dissociated the H to generate O* intermediates and the combination of two O* moieties finally formed one 1O2. They also proposed that the Fe–N4 site exhibits moderate and near-average Gibbs free energy in each reaction step, thus possessing better activity than other single atom sites (Co, Mn, Ni, and Cu). In their system, the O source of 1O2 is totally from HSO5 –. It is also observed that the dissolved oxygen can be the O source for 1O2 generation (Fig. 9(d)). For example, Yang et al. [126] reported a support effect on the generation of 1O2, where a nanodiamond support could induce the compressive strain of the curved Fe–N4 sites and increase the energy level of Fe 3dz 2 orbital to donate an electron to the O2 molecule for subsequent generation of 1O2 (Fig. 9(d)). Current studies mainly focus on the 1O2 generation pathway on the Fe–N4 site due to its favorable energetic characteristics. Wang et al. [125] engineered a Fe–N2–O2 site to enhance PMS adsorption and facilitate its decomposition into OH* and O* moieties for 1O2 generation (Fig. 10 ). The probes for the direct identification of 1O2 involve the EPR trapping agent, 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine (TEMP), and chemical probes such as 9,10-diphenanthraquinone (DPA) and 1,3-diphenylisobenzofuran (DPBF) [27,125]. In the O2 •– mediated pathway for 1O2 generation, the involvement of O2 •– intermediates can be determined through direct detection by EPR (Fig. 11(a) ) [126,127]. While for the pathway mediated by surface O* involving multiple intermediates (as depicted in Fig. 9(b)), an experimental identification of these intermediates poses a significant challenge, necessitating the application of theoretical tools. Gao et al. performed calculations on the Gibbs free energy of various possible intermediates, including OH*, O*, and OOH*, throughout PMS activation (Figs. 11(b) and (c)). They proposed a PMS → OH* → O* → 1O2 process as the most reasonable pathway for 1O2 generation based on the thermodynamical considerations [27]. The employed quenchers for 1O2 include furfuryl alcohol (FFA) [119,120,122,123,128], L-histidine [119-121,124,127] and NaN3 [27,125] for the study of the oxidation contribution of 1O2. However, researchers have realized that these quenchers also rapidly react with PMS or radical species, which might overestimate the oxidation contribution of 1O2 [6,44,146]. An EPR trapping agent, TEMP, can be used as a quencher alternative [29,142], while its alkaline property may change the solution pH at a high dosage. The alkali condition will also accelerate the self-decomposition of PMS to generate 1O2 [155]. Solvent exchange experiments have also been carried out to study the role of 1O2, where D2O was usually used to replace H2O by taking advantage of the solvent-dependent lifetime of 1O2 (the 1O2 quenching rate constants k d(H2O) = 2.5 × 105 s–1 and k d(D2O) = 1.6 × 104 s–1) [123,125]. Nevertheless, the solvent exchange methods may alter the surface properties of catalysts and slow down the overall kinetics, which needs to be considered [156]. 3.5 Generation, regulation, and identification of catalyst-PMS* complexes The electron-transfer process (ETP) can directly capture electrons from pollutants with the formed catalyst-PMS* complex as reactive species. This complex is formed by the electronic rearrangement of PMS owing to the charge transfer from single atom Fe sites to the adsorbed PMS. Despite that the O–O bond is not cleaved, this activated PMS (denoted as a catalyst-PMS* complex) possesses elevated oxidation potential, which can directly oxidize (electron-rich) pollutants with a lower oxidation potential through an electron transfer process. This nonradical process has been first reported on CuO and carbon materials [157,158] and then realized on many other catalysts [159]. The advantages of ETP involve (1) high selectivity toward electron-rich substances; (2) excellent resistance to complicated water matrices; (3) effectiveness in a wide pH working window; (4) absence of toxic halogen-containing products; (5) high PMS utilization efficiency; and (6) tunable oxidation capacity via regulating the PMS adsorption capacity of the catalyst [156]. A few studies reported the ETP dominant oxidation of organic pollutants on SAICs [129-133]. The ETP has been studied mainly from experimental aspects, while the mechanistic exploration from the theoretical aspects is still at a preliminary stage. The formation of the catalyst-PMS* does not involve the fracture of PMS and the pollutant oxidation is driven by the potential difference between the formed catalyst-PMS* and a pollutant. Therefore, the work function which was defined as the difference between the electrostatic potential energy and the Fermi energy can be used as a descriptor, where electrons predominantly transfer from the object with a lower work function to that with a higher work function [160]. From this point of view, hydroxy O adsorption structure possesses the highest work function, which may contribute most to the ETP process (Fig. 6(b)) [144]. Besides the work function, other catalyst-related descriptors such as chemical potential (μ), global electrophilicity index (ɷ) [161], and potential difference between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of pollutants and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of catalysts [162], as well as pollutant-related descriptors of Hammett constants (i.e., σ, σ+, and σ‒) and Fukui function (f +, f ‒, and f 0) [163], are also developed for establishing quantitative structure-activity relationships (QSARs) in ETP. To enhance the formation of a catalyst-PMS* complex, Peng et al. [133] developed a Fe–N2–O2 site that favors the terminal O adsorption structure of PMS, resulting in improved electron transfer between the atomic Fe site and PMS (Fig. 12 ). In addition, the Fe–N3 coordination can increase the density of states around the Fermi level and promote the hybridization between O 2p orbital of PMS and Fe 3d orbital of single atom Fe site, thus facilitating the generation of the catalyst-PMS* complex (Fig. 12) [129]. Given that the formation of a metastable catalyst-PMS* complex does not entail the cleavage of PMS, direct identification of the catalyst-PMS* complex can be achieved by in situ Raman spectra. Typically, the peak of the adsorbed peroxo species of the activated PMS* will appear at ca. 830 cm–1 when PMS interacts with the SAICs (Fig. 13(a) ) [130]. Moreover, the oxidizing capacity of the catalyst-PMS* can be quantitatively determined using electrochemical techniques such as open-circuit potential tests. The open-circuit potential of a SAIC will increase immediately upon the addition of PMS, eventually reaching a plateau of the potential value of the catalyst-PMS* complex (Fig. 13(b)) [133,142]. Additionally, the oxidation behavior by a catalyst-PMS* complex can be simulated through chronoamperometry by applying a potential identical to that measured during the open-circuit potential test for the complex [142]. Currently, there are no available chemical probes for catalyst-PMS* complexes. The characteristic peak of 5,5-dimethyl-2-pyrrolidone-N-oxyl (DMPOX) may be observed in the ETP system when DMPO is used [29]. However, the ETP can also induce the oxidation of TEMP to 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxyl (TEMPO), showing the identical phenomenon to 1O2 [6]. Meanwhile, the 1O2 quenchers such as FFA can also inhibit pollutant oxidation in a sole ETP system due to the low oxidation potential of FFA [14]. Therefore, special attentions need to be taken on distinguishing 1O2 and catalyst-PMS* during the evaluation of their contributions. Further distinguishing methods involve monitoring the PMS decomposition behavior with or without the addition of pollutants, separating the PMS activation and pollutant oxidation in two separate cells/steps, and establishing the quantitative structure/activity relationships [156,164]. 3.6 Generation, regulation, and identification of HVI Since high-valent iron-oxo species were revealed in the Fenton reaction [165], researchers have believed the generation of FeIV=O (or FeV=O) in many Fenton-like reactions including PMS-based systems [15,166]. The standard reduction potential of FeIV=O is estimated to be 1.3–1.95 VNHE depending on different oxidation pathways [166]. FeIV=O possesses moderate oxidation kinetics (102 to 104 L mol–1 s–1) but a much higher half-time (ca. 7 s) than radicals, giving rise to remarkably peroxide utilization efficiency and thus low chemical consumption. Many studies reported the generation of FeIV=O [134-139,142] or FeV=O [140,141,143] as dominant reactive species on Fe–N4 sites for pollutant oxidation. It has been widely proposed that FeIV=O/FeV=O is generated by heterolytic cleavage of the O–O bond in the Fe–N4-PMS complex [134-136,138-140], similar to the process in homogeneous catalysis (Fig. 14(a) ). The generation of FeIV=O/FeV=O can be regulated by the spin-state of the atomic Fe sites, with high-spin (FeIII S = 5/2) sites displaying a higher tendency to bond with PMS, thus enabling the heterolytic cleavage of O–O bond to produce FeV=O (Fig. 14(b)) [143]. In addition, a coupled electron-proton transfer process was also proposed for HVI selective generation by establishing a local electric field around the metal atom sites [167]. However, there are many controversies around this FeIV=O/FeV=O generation pathway, including (1) the PMS adsorption sites, (2) the oxygen source in FeIV=O/FeV=O, and iii) the determination and differentiation of FeIV=O and FeV=O. The sites of hydroxy O [136,140], peroxy O [135,139], and terminal O [141-143] are all reported to be adsorbed on the single atom Fe sites. Similarly, all the hydroxy O [136,140], peroxy O [135,139], and terminal O [143] have been reported as the oxygen resource in FeIV=O/FeV=O. When one PMS molecule is adsorbed on the single atom Fe site for generating FeIV=O/FeV=O, O–O and O–H bonds are cleaved for hydroxy O adsorption structure, which requires less energy than those for peroxo O (cleavage of O–O and S–O bonds) and terminal O (cleavage of S–O bond) adsorption structures (Fig. 6(a)). However, the adsorption energy of the terminal O adsorption model is the most negative, which is not consistent with the free energy for FeIV=O/FeV=O generation. Therefore, the PMS adsorption site and oxygen source in FeIV=O/FeV=O seem hard to be conclusively determined based on the current four pyridinic N coordinated single atom Fe active sites, as well as the FeIV=O/FeV=O generation pathway. In this regard, Cheng et al. [142] discovered that Fe loading is a critical but overlooked factor in FeIV=O generation on the Fe–N4 site. With the increase of Fe loading, the atomically dispersed Fe sites become closer and the adjacent Fe sites will form to affect the catalytic behavior. Three kinds of Fe sites with different Fe1–Fe1 distances were identified involving Fe1–Fe1 distance > 5 Å (regarded as the individual one and denoted as Fe–N4 site), 4–5 Å (denoted as 2Fe–N4 site) and < 4 Å (denoted as Fe2–N6 site). When PMS is adsorbed on the atomic Fe site with a single-site adsorption structure, its adsorption strength follows the order of Fe2–N6 > 2Fe–N4 > Fe–N4. However, for 2Fe–N4 site that possesses a site distance matching to the molecular size of PMS (ca. 4.1 Å), the terminal O and hydroxy O of PMS will be collaboratively adsorbed on the adjacent Fe atoms to form a more stable dual-site adsorption structure (Fig. 14(c)). This dual-site adsorption structure could significantly enhance the charge transfer from Fe sites to PMS for the cleavage of O–O and O–H bonds, requiring the lowest free energy for FeIV=O generation compared with other structures. Therefore, the real active sites for FeIV=O generation are the adjacent Fe sites with a Fe1–Fe1 distance of 4–5 Å rather than the commonly assumed isolated Fe–N4 site. The terminal O and hydroxy O atoms are each adsorbed on the two Fe atoms of the 2Fe–N4 site, and the oxygen source in FeIV=O is the hydroxy O in PMS (Fig. 14(c)). Moreover, generation of FeIV=O/FeV=O can be enhanced by increasing the electron density at the Fe center to facilitate charge transfer to PMS via coordinated atom modulation [136-138], guest group modulation [139], and support regulation [135] (Fig. 15 ). For example, construction of a Fe–N2–O2 moiety can elevate the energy levels of occupied frontier orbitals, thereby enhancing the electron-donating ability of atomic Fe site [136]. Altering the coordinated N atoms from pyridinic N to pyrrolic N can lower the d-band center (–0.29 eV vs. –0.05 eV for pyrrolic and pyridinic N, respectively) and raise the oxidation state of Fe sites, generating antibonding states with lower levels and higher occupancy for more favorable generation of FeIV=O species [138]. Additionally, introducing an extra axial N coordination (Fe–N5) can enhance the electron density around the Fe site, facilitating O–O bond dissociation and HSO4 – desorption for FeIV=O generation [139]. For the FeIV=O/FeV=O differentiation, FeIV=O generation from an FeIII–N4 site [134,135,138,139] or FeII–N4 site [136,137], and FeV=O generation from an FeIII–N4 site [141,143] are reported. The valence state of FeII/FeIII can be identified by XPS and XANES, and the aqueous FeIV=O and FeV=O can be distinguished through spectroscopy methods [168,169]. However, these methods are not effective for the identification of surface FeIV=O/FeV=O formed on the single atom Fe site. Cheng et al. [142] observed that addition of hydroxylamine (HA) as a FeII/FeIII cycle promoter barely affects the methyl phenyl sulfoxide (PMSO) oxidation on FeII–N4 sites. The oxygen atom transfer between HVI and PMSO resulted in the two-electron reduction of HVI. Therefore, combined with the majority content of FeII in the catalyst, they identified the HVI as FeIV=O, which was generated from the two-electron oxidation of FeII without the formation of FeIII or FeV=O. The most widely used probe for the identification of FeIV=O/FeV=O is PMSO, which can be selectively transformed to methyl phenyl sulfone (PMSO2) through the oxygen atom transfer reaction by FeIV=O/FeV=O [135-137]. The surface FeIV=O/FeV=O species and the reaction intermediates can also be identified by in situ Raman spectra. The FeIV=O/FeV=O species exhibit a typical characteristic peak at ca. 840 cm–1 when PMS interacts with atomic Fe site (Fig. 16(a) ) [135,139,142,143]. Notably, this peak displays a higher Raman shift compared to that of catalyst-PMS* complexes, indicating that the FeIV=O species possess a greater electron density and, consequently, a stronger oxidizing capacity than the catalyst-PMS* complexes. Employing time-resolved Raman analysis allows for the observation of the evolution of FeIV=O from PMS decomposition on the catalyst surface and the key intermediates during the reaction (Fig. 16(b)) [135,167]. For example, Song et al. detected a peak corresponding to HSO4 – (at ca. 1060 cm–1), which initially appeared and intensified in the early reaction stages but diminished with prolonged reaction time, in the generation of high-valent metal-oxo species [167]. In conjunction with similar results from synchrotron radiation-based FTIR spectra, they identified HSO4 – as a key intermediate and proposed a coupled electron-proton transfer mechanism for high-valent metal-oxo species formation (Fig. 16(c)). In exploration of the oxidation contribution of FeIV=O/FeV=O, PMSO can be employed but the dosage needs a particular consideration to avoid the excess consumption of PMS by PMSO via direction reactions [135,142]. The molar ratio of PMSO to PMS of 10:1 is normally recommended. Both the conversion efficiency and selectivity should be considered when compared Fe-SAC with control groups as PMS only will also lead to high PMSO2 selectivity close to 100%. 3.7 Structure-activity/selectivity relationships Due to the complexity of PMS activation with multiple steps and ROS generation with multiple reaction intermediates, diverse ROS are produced even at a singular atomic Fe site. While theoretical tools can efficiently determine the energetically optimal PMS adsorption structure, the ultimate generation of specific ROS necessitates moderate reaction free energy in each reaction step [27]. Therefore, the control of ROS selectivity requires managing both PMS adsorption energy and the reaction free energy of crucial elementary steps. In this context, regulating the electronic structure of the active site is an effective way to govern PMS activation activity and ROS selectivity for establishing the relationships. This involves a moderate increase of the charge density of Fe sites by constructing Fe–N2–O2 and Fe–N5 sites to enhance 1O2 and FeIV=O generation, as well as an Fe–N3 site for catalyst-PMS* complex generation. Further elevation of the charge density by Fe–N3–P1 and Fe–N4 (pyrrolic N) sites favors radical generation. However, the mononuclear nature of the isolated single-atom site with limited charge density restricts further regulation and augmentation of the electron-donating capability of atomic Fe sites. Constructing a dual-site PMS adsorption structure holds a promise in significantly boosting charge transfer and overcoming the constraints, particularly by leveraging intrinsic adjacent metallic sites while increasing the metal loading in SACs. The enhanced generation of FeIV=O on the adjacent Fe–N4 site with a specific atomic distance of 4.1 Å serves as compelling proof-of-concept [142]. Different ROS typically demonstrate varying pollutant oxidation capabilities. Their activities in various SAICs/PMS systems can be compared using a normalized rate constant for the oxidation of the typical emerging contaminant, bisphenol A (BPA) (Fig. 17 ). While radical species inherently exhibit higher reactivity (second-order rate constants with pollutants) compared to nonradicals [170], the superior electron utilization efficiency and high selectivity of nonradical species/pathway results in a faster pollutant oxidation rate in SAICs/PMS systems, especially the ETP nonradical oxidation by a catalyst-PMS* complex. Owing to the moderate oxidizing capacity of the catalyst-PMS* complex, the ETP oxidation process falls short of mineralizing organic pollutants to CO2 and H2O. Instead, pollutants tend to transform into polymerized products through electron-transfer oxidation, which can be enriched on the catalyst surface via π–π interaction, significantly reducing the concentration of dissolved organic carbon and minimizing the usage of PMS [156]. Considering the extended treatment time by radicals and the carbon-neutral targets, the nonradical-based polymerization process emerges as a promising avenue for reducing CO2 emission and recycling resources from wastewater [171,172]. Moreover, the controlled generation of radical/nonradical species based on SACs/PMS systems for regulated redox reactions holds the potential to introduce new strategies in organic synthesis and other catalytic domains [173,174]. 4 Conclusions and outlook The heterogeneous PMS activation technology provides an effective and versatile way for water decontamination, by which various radicals and nonradical species are generated to achieve the demand-oriented deep mineralization or selective removal of organic pollutants in complex water matrices. The bottleneck of this technology lies in establishing the structure-activity-selectivity relationships to achieve the effective and controllable generation of reactive species owing to the insufficient exposure of active sites and structural complexity of NP catalysts. SACs with maximum atom utilization efficiency and uniform active sites show great potential for solving the above problems. Particularly, SAICs have attracted much research interest owing to the abundance, durability, versatility, tunability, and environmental friendliness of Fe element. Various SAICs have been fabricated for PMS activation to generate diverse reactive species involving radicals, 1O2, catalyst-PMS*, and HVI for efficient water purification. We reviewed the generation pathways of these reactive species at the molecular level, analyzed the critical impacts from the geometric and electronic structures of single atom Fe centers, and evaluated the identification methods of these reactive species. The mechanism from single atom Fe sites can be extended to other metal sites and help understand the determining factors of reactive species generation and correlate these to the properties of catalysts. Combined with the well-developed synthetic strategies and in-depth understanding of the structure evolution of single atom metal sites, the desired active site structure can be deliberately designed and synthesized. However, limited by in situ/operando study of the PMS activation process, our understanding of the mechanism of interaction between active sites with both PMS and pollutants and the dynamic evolution of the active sites during the catalytic process is still inadequate. State-of-the-art in situ/operando techniques including in situ TEM, operando XAS, and in situ Mössbauer spectroscopy can be used for the evaluation of reaction mechanism of PMS activation and better design of SACs for environmental remediation. The utilization of in situ FTIR and Raman spectra have been extensive in detecting key intermediates and exploring the PMS activation pathway, benefitting from their evident fingerprints and damage-free characteristics. However, up to now, most of these in situ techniques are performed under overdosed PMS conditions to amplify signal intensity. Due to the potential alternation of generated reactive species with varying PMS concentration and the structural similarities of some intermediates for different reactive species, such as surface-adsorbed PMS* [142,175], conflicting experimental results may arise under these conditions. Therefore, there is a critical need for optimizing experimental setups in in situ FTIR and Raman measurements to reliably identify reaction intermediates during PMS activation. To this end, dedicated efforts are urgently required for the development of special reaction cells to achieve operando conditions. Additionally, advanced techniques like surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) and synchrotron-based IR spectroscopy can be implemented to enhance sensitivity for detecting transient intermediates in operando conditions [176,177]. Furthermore, the coupling of multiple analytical techniques is advantageous for obtaining reliable insights. While DFT calculations have emerged as powerful tools for providing mechanistic insights into the PMS activation process, their utility is constrained by time and computational resources. DFT is not suitable for filtering through numerous models and predictions. In this context, machine learning (ML) and QSARs serve as convenient and reliable tools for building predictive models of material properties and reaction intermediates. The integration of these tools holds a promise for comprehensively understanding the evolution of reactive species from the molecular to the macroscopic level [178]. In addition, the catalytic activity of SACs is dependent on the mononuclearity of the M1 sites and the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI). Precise modulation of the geometric and electronic structures of SACs and SMSI can optimize the center metal properties and consequently catalytic behaviors. Despite the merits of improving the utilization of metal atoms, the mononuclearity of the M1 sites in SACs makes them not versatile in catalytic systems that require multiple adsorption sites. The emergence of dual-atom catalysts (DACs) can change the situation by increasing the number of metal nuclei [179,180]. The introduction of a second metal (either homonuclear or heteronuclear) site can modulate the electronic structure of the host M1 sites or provide a binuclear metal site for optimized reactant(s) adsorption configuration [181]. Our previous studies have verified the critical role of adjacent metal sites in SACs-activated persulfate systems for activity enhancement and pathway regulation [29,142]. Further research regarding the controllable construction of binuclear or multinuclear sites and their role in PMS activation is required, despite that the interplays can be complicated. Furthermore, the engineering consideration of SACs for realistic water treatment requires the development of advanced reaction systems to immobilize the SACs on a low-cost but robust support. Anchoring the SACs onto membranes can be an appealing way due to increased contact areas for surface reaction and mass transfer during the flow-through process. Designated pore engineering of membranes to intensify the nanoconfinement effect will remarkably intensify the reaction kinetics and utilization efficiency of ROS, particularly for free radicals [44]. Hui Zhang (School of Resource and Environmental Sciences, Wuhan University) received his Ph.D. degree from South China University of Technology (China) in 1995. Since then, he has been working at Wuhan University and is currently a professor. His research interests focus on environmental chemistry, environmental catalysis and advanced oxidation technologies for environmental remediation. He has published more than 180 refereed journal papers with citation over 18000 and H-index of 77. He was recognized as highly cited researcher (Cross-Field) in 2022 and 2023 by Clarivate and was in the list of highly cited Chinese authors (Environmental Science and Engineering) by Elsevier in 2020, 2021 and 2022. He served as a member of the editorial board of Journal of Hazardous Materials. Xiaoguang Duan (School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, Australia) received his Ph.D. degree from Curtin University in 2016. He is currently an Associate Professor and ARC DECRA Fellow (2021) & ARC Future Fellow (2024). His research areas focus on environmental science, green catalysis, functional materials, advanced water purification technologies, and computational science. He has published over 300 peer-reviewed research papers including over 70 ESI Highly Cited Papers (1%). His publications received >32000 citations and H-index of 93. Based on research excellence, he was awarded the ACS Catalysis ECR Award, and JMCA Emerging Investigator Award. He was awarded the MIT Technology Review Innovators Under 35 (MIT IU35, Asian Pacific) in 2021 and ES&T James J. Morgan Award in 2022. He was recognized as the Global Highly Cited Researcher (Clarivate Analytics) in two fields of ‘Environment/Ecology’ and ‘Chemistry’ in 2022‒2023, and in ‘Cross-Field’ in 2020‒2021. Shaobin Wang (School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Adelaide, Australia) received his B. Sc degree from Peking University (China), and Ph.D. degree from The University of Queensland (Australia). He is now a Professor and ARC Laureate Fellow (2023). His research interests focus on nanomaterial synthesis and application for adsorption and catalysis, fuel and energy conversion and environmental remediation. He has published more than 700 refereed journal papers with citation over 88000 and H-index of 164. He was awarded 2012 Thomson Reuters Citation & Innovation Awards in Australia. He is also the Clarivate Analytics Highly Cited Researcher in ‘Engineering’, and ‘Chemistry’ and ‘Environment/Ecology’ for 2016‒2022. He also served as the editor of Applied Catalysis B, Chemical Engineering Journal Advances, and Journal of Colloid and Interface Science.

coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Heterogeneous peroxymonosulfate (PMS)-based oxidation technology for water treatment requires innovative catalysts for efficient and selective production of desired reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as free radicals, singlet oxygen, catalyst-PMS* complexes, and high-valent metal-oxo species. Single-atom catalysts are featured with the maximized atom utilization as well as uniform and well-defined active sites, holding a great promise for effective and selective PMS activation. However, the structure-activity/selectivity relationships have not yet been well revealed owing to multiple ROS generation pathways and their complex interplay. Herein, we focus on the mechanisms of PMS activation by single-atom iron catalysts and identify the relationships of the geometric and electronic structures of single atom Fe centers to selective production of different reactive species/pathways. Moreover, in situ/operando techniques to monitor the dynamic evolution of active sites under practical working conditions and design of binuclear metal sites for synergistic catalysis will also be discussed.

coredata.dc:title: Single-atom iron catalysts for peroxymonosulfate-based advanced oxidation processes: Coordination structure versus reactive species
